Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH:Ecological interactions mediate the effects of climatic stress on populations: dissecting the direct and indirect effects of climate on plants
Award.AbstractNarration:
Most projections of shifts in species distributions with climate change assume that geographic ranges are strongly determined by abiotic stresses including temperature and precipitation. However, ecologists have generally thought that species ranges in areas where such stresses are relatively low are strongly influenced by biotic interactions such as predation or parasitism. Though this long-standing hypothesis contradicts the assumptions behind most projections of future species distributions, there are few tests of the relative strength of abiotic and biotic interactions across meaningful portions of species ranges or along stress gradients. This project will use field and greenhouse experiments to assess the effect of pollination on performance of the common, understory plant Hibiscus meyeri along an aridity gradient in East Africa, adding to on-going studies of herbivory and interactions between plants in the same system. The work will help develop species distribution modeling by using H. meyeri to construct predictive distribution models that vary in their incorporation of multiple biotic interactions. Results will help to show when biotic interactions must be included to understand how species will be influenced by changes in temperature and precipitation.

The broader impacts of this research include provision of scientific information for the conservation of biodiversity and national and international training for students and outreach to resource managers and users. Many pollinators and large herbivores are threatened in Africa and around the globe, and this work will help show the potential effects of their extirpation on the functioning of ecological systems. The project will train U.S. and Kenyan undergraduate students and a U.S. Ph.D. student, and collaborate with the National Museums and the Mpala Research Centre in Kenya.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ecology of species’ geographic distributions, or where a species is present versus where it is not present, has long fascinated ecologists, and is becoming increasingly urgent to understand given accelerating human-caused climate change. Most recent predictions of changes in species’ distributions with climate change assume that shifts in distributions will track shifts in climate. This assumption relies on the idea that species’ distributions are solely determined by their tolerance of different climate conditions. For example, a species only occurs at intermediate temperatures with moderately high rainfall, with no effect of competitors, predators, or diseases. In contrast, ecologists have generally assumed that climate is of primary importance in stressful portions of a species’ range (for example, very cold or low-rainfall areas) with unstressful portions of a species’ range (for example, warm or productive areas) more strongly controlled by biotic interactions, such as parasite load, predation pressure, or herbivory. This project evaluates how variation in climate across a species’ range alters the influence of three such biotic interactions on population performance of a common African plant. This work will provide a direct test of when and where climate or biotic interactions are key drivers of population performance, and thus geographic distributions.

While we have not yet compiled all the data necessary to robustly test for population-level effects of biotic interactions and abiotic stress, we have preliminary results on two biotic interactions, herbivory and competition among plants, that suggest that some types of biotic interactions are consistent with ecologists’ predictions, but some are not. Herbivores exert stronger effects on population-level variables in unstressful, high-rainfall areas, consistent with past predictions. Effects of competition among plants on growth is stronger in high-rainfall areas than in low-rainfall areas. However, effects of competition on offspring number, a population-level measurement of plant success, do not substantially differ in high- and low-rainfall areas. Interestingly, for plant growth, herbivores categorically change the effect of neighbors, with neighbors exerting negative (competitive) or positive (facilitative) effects as a function of both herbivore presence and rainfall amount. These examples suggest that general predictions abut what shapes species ranges may be too simplistic, with interacting biotic interactions that differ in their effects on species’ geographic distributions.

This project has and will continue to further our understanding of when and where biotic interactions are important. This understanding will help us to better predict when and where species will shift with climate change by identifying locations in which we need to identify and quantify important biotic interactions to accurately predict these shifts, and locations where we do not need to consider biotic interactions. The majority of this field work was conducted in Kenya, employing 10 high-school educated Kenyans and giving them transferrable training as naturalists, as well as English language, data collection, and experimental design skills. This work has also involved bringing two female recent undergraduates or undergraduates to Kenya to conduct their own project, one of which will result in a senior thesis. Finally, one of the primary investigators has contributed to multiple outreach activities in Kenya and the U.S., including volunteering to bring Kenyan female students into the field, and collaborating with faculty and professionals in Kenya and diverse institutions in the U.S.
